options.A: patient who underwent radiation therapy for breast cancer 28 months ago presents with numbness in the 3rd and 4th fingers and arm pain. What is the next best step in management?

50+ year old male presents with weakness in hand flexors and quadriceps. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: In a patient with Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP), what is the characteristic clinical finding?

options.A: Progressive, symmetrical muscle weakness with absent deep tendon reflexes
options.B: Asymmetrical muscle weakness with preserved reflexes

question_text: Scenario of progressive bulbar palsy: what is the diagnosis?

options.A: Progressive bulbar palsy

question_text: In the context of periodic paralysis, which of the following statements is true regarding serum potassium levels?

options.A: Always low in hypokalemic periodic paralysis
options.B: Always high in hyperkalemic periodic paralysis
options.C: Normal but may be high in hypokalemic periodic paralysis

question_text: What percentage of Guillain-Barré syndrome patients experience recurrence?

options.A: patient presents with clear symptoms of periodic paralysis lasting for hours. What is the next test that should be performed?

question_text: In patients with generalized Myasthenia Gravis, positive AChR-binding antibodies are found in what percentage of cases?

options.A: May induce an attack
patient presents with upper extremity painful neuropathy and atrophy. What is the recommended treatment?
35-year-old obese female has delayed muscle relaxation, complains of tingling in her hands, and has slight bradycardia in her vital signs. What investigation should be done?
patient presents with hand stiffness that worsens and becomes weak with exercise and cold. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by paralysis that typically occurs in the first to second decade of life and predominantly affects males?

options.A: Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis

question_text: In congenital myasthenia gravis, which channel types are involved?

options.A: Slow channel

question_text: In an elderly patient presenting with neuropathy and weakness, which of the following is a recommended diagnostic procedure if amyloidosis is suspected?

options.A: Fat aspiration

55-year-old male has a history of lower limb weakness for days, initially starting with numbness and tingling. Days later, the weakness involved the upper limbs and was associated with hyperhidrosis in the lower limbs and facial involvement. He also has a history of epigastric pain. Examination shows bilateral lower limb weakness. He received an influenza vaccine 2 weeks prior to the onset of symptoms. What is the diagnosis?
case of Bell's palsy underwent EMG. Which muscle is likely to show findings?

question_text: What is the most sensitive test to diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG)?

options.A: Single fiber EMG

patient presented with right arm weakness that was slowly progressive for 5 years and then became static, involving multiple muscles while sparing the brachioradialis. The patient denies pain or trauma. What is expected to be found?

question_text: In a scenario of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) on day 5, what will the nerve conduction study (NCS) show?

options.A: Sural sparing with affected median and ulnar nerves
options.B: Normal sensory and motor nerve conduction velocities
options.C: Reduced compound muscle action potential (CMAP) amplitudes without demyelination
options.D: Increased distal motor latencies with conduction block

question_text: Anti-MuSK Myasthenia gravis is characterized by which of the following features?

options.A: Tongue fasciculation and atrophy
patient with ALS presents with fatigue. What is the next best step in management?
patient with back pain radiating to the left lower limb and normal ankle reflexes is evaluated. Which muscle is involved?

question_text: Which of the following electrodiagnostic tests is most helpful in the diagnosis of periodic paralysis?

options.A: High-frequency repetitive stimulation
patient has muscle stiffness that worsens with exercise. What is the likely diagnosis?
poorly controlled type 1 diabetic male with an HbA1c of 14% became controlled one week ago and started to complain of pain. What is the best management option?

question_text: Most common presentation of post-polio syndrome:

options.A: New muscle weakness and fatigue

question_text: Most common presentation of post-polio syndrome:

options.A: New onset muscle weakness and fatigue

38-year-old male presents with a history of generalized weakness, a "spring" face, and respiratory issues. Examination reveals hyporeflexia. He came to the ER and received potassium supplements, but later repeated the same attacks weekly. His potassium level is 2.6 (low). What is the most accurate management?
patient with a picture of Myasthenia Gravis (eye, proximal weakness, and bulbar symptoms) and a flat tongue. Which of the following antibodies is supposed to be positive?

question_text: How to differentiate between C8 and ulnar neuropathy?

options.A: Abnormal SNAP
options.D: Sensory loss in the medial forearm

question_text: What is the characteristic clinical presentation of Multifocal Motor Neuropathy (MMN)?

options.A: Subacute onset of patchy, asymmetrical weakness without sensory involvement
options.B: Rapidly progressive weakness with sensory loss
options.C: Bilateral symmetrical weakness with sensory symptoms
options.D: Isolated sensory symptoms in the lower limbs

question_text: What is the nerve supply to the sartorius muscle?

options.A: Femoral nerve

question_text: In a scenario with congenital myasthenia gravis, where the patient has hand involvement and proximal upper and lower limb weakness, what is the likely diagnosis?

options.A: Slow channel myasthenia gravis
patient presented with back pain, facial sweating, and intermittent epigastric pain associated with progressive distal sensory loss and weakness. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: What is commonly associated with anti-MuSK antibodies?

options.A: Normal thyroid function
options.C: Predominant facial and bulbar muscle weakness

question_text: An infant with hypotonia, macroglossia, feeding problems, trouble breathing, muscle weakness, and an enlarged heart. What is the defective enzyme?

options.A: Acid fast Maltase (Acid alpha-glucosidase)

question_text: In a scenario about a patient with static weakness sparing the brachioradialis, what would you expect to see on MRI?

options.A: Spinal Segment Atrophy

question_text: In a case of limb girdle muscular dystrophy type 2A, what is the recommended diagnostic test?

options.A: Echocardiogram

question_text: What is the most common cause of femoral neuropathy?

options.A: Trauma

question_text: Kearns-Sayre syndrome

options.A: Is characterized by progressive external ophthalmoplegia, pigmentary retinopathy, and onset before age 20
options.B: Is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting the peripheral nerves
options.C: Primarily affects the lower motor neurons causing muscle atrophy
options.D: Is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene

question_text: In a patient with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), what is a characteristic finding on EMG?

options.A: Slow conduction velocity
case with features of POEM presents with lower limb edema and neuropathy. What is the likely associated factor?

question_text: In the management of acute attacks of hypokalemic periodic paralysis, potassium is typically given orally at what dosage?

options.A: 5-10 mEq every 15-30 minutes

question_text: In a scenario of AIDP, what are the early findings in nerve conduction studies (NCS)?

options.A: Prolonged or absent F wave with absent H reflex
options.B: Increased amplitude of compound muscle action potential (CMAP)
options.C: Normal conduction velocity with reduced sensory nerve action potential (SNAP) amplitude
options.D: Early recruitment of motor units on electromyography

options.A: diabetic patient presents with features of small fiber neuropathy (pain worse at night, intact reflexes). What is the best treatment?

question_text: What is one of the diagnostic criteria for Guillain-Barré syndrome?

options.A: Routine laboratory tests

question_text: Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to which type of peripheral neuropathy?

options.A: Sensory neuropathy

question_text: Distal acquired demyelinating symmetric neuropathy (DADS) is characterized by which of the following?

options.A: Proximal weakness
options.B: Sensory deficits more than motor deficits

question_text: EMG

options.A: Measures nerve conduction velocity
options.B: Records electrical activity of muscles at rest and during contraction
options.C: Is primarily used to assess brain activity

question_text: An anti-MuSK patient who developed hepatotoxicity with azathioprine, what medication should be given?

options.A: Rituximab

patient has a fracture in the acetabulum and notices numbness on the dorsum of the foot with weak dorsiflexion. Where is the lesion likely located?

question_text: In congenital myasthenic syndromes, what is the gene defect that causes worsening of symptoms with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors?

options.A: DOK7

question_text: What is the effect of oral potassium in the management of Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis?

options.A: Prevents attack

question_text: What is a common presenting feature of Multifocal Motor Neuropathy (MMN)?

options.A: Upper motor neuron signs

question_text: Congenital myasthenia gravis with distal and proximal weakness, facial involvement worsened with acetylcholinesterase inhibitor?

options.A: DOK7

question_text: In a scenario typical for paramyotonia congenita, what is the gene involved?

options.A: Sodium channel (SCN4A)

patient with dysferlinopathy presents with a CK level elevated 35 times the normal and mild upper limb weakness, mainly in the lower limbs, with significant calf atrophy and weak dorsiflexion. What is the likely diagnosis?

question_text: An infant presents with respiratory issues, electrical myotonia, and macroglossia. What is the likely diagnosis?

options.A: Pompe

young lady post-vaginal hysterectomy presents with weakness in hip adductors and hip flexion. Which nerve is likely affected?

question_text: In a Guillain-Barré syndrome scenario, what is the predicting factor for intubation?

options.A: Presence of dysautonomia

options.A: Prolonged or absent F wave with absent H Reflex

options.C: Normal sensory nerve action potentials with reduced motor amplitudes
options.D: Decreased distal motor latency with normal F wave

options.A: patient wakes up from sleep with right upper limb pain followed by weakness and multiple nerve involvement. What is the likely diagnosis?
patient with Sjögren's disease presents with neurological symptoms. Which of the following is a possible presentation?

question_text: Which factor is known to trigger an attack in Paramyotonia Congenita?

options.A: Rest

female patient presents with right Bell's palsy. You performed the blink reflex test, and the EMG showed axonal injury. Which muscle is involved?

patient came with channelopathy. What is the best workup?

options.A: Onion bulb formation

question_text: What is the most common myopathy in elderly individuals above 50 years of age?

options.A: Inclusion body myositis

question_text: What is the first-line treatment for Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)?

options.A: Plasmapheresis
patient presents with subacute flaccid quadriplegia following diarrheal illnesses, with sparing of the face and sensation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: What is the most common myopathy disease in patients above 50 years of age?

options.A: Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM)

question_text: Which of the following muscles is innervated by the ulnar nerve?

options.A: Adductor pollicis

question_text: Which of the following is a function of the femoral nerve?

options.A: Hip flexion (via Iliopsoas, partly femoral)
options.C: Medial area of thigh decreased sensation (Saphenous nerve, branch of femoral)

options.A: young man played football for one day, developed generalized weakness mainly in the proximal limbs, and the next day his urine changed color to dark brown and he had muscle pain. What is the most likely cause?

question_text: In a case of dysautonomia with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), what is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

options.A: Protein electrophoresis

question_text: In a case of a patient with colchicine toxicity-induced myopathy, who presents with high CK levels and EMG findings of prominent fibrillations, positive sharp waves, and excessively polyphasic motor action potentials in the proximal muscles that are brief and small in amplitude, what is the cause?

options.A: Colchicine

question_text: In congenital Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), which of the following symptoms is typically absent on EMG?

options.A: Hypotonia
